title: 113_hr5477
content: The Act is titled the "Enhancing Educational Opportunities for all Students Act" and includes provisions for Title I portability, allowance of home school expenses as qualified education expenses, elimination of Coverdell Education Savings Account contribution limitation, and 529 programs for elementary and secondary education expenses. TITLE I of the ESEA Portability allows Title I funds to follow low-income children at the state level. State educational agencies can allocate grant funds based on the number of eligible children enrolled in public and private schools within their jurisdiction. An eligible child is defined as aged 5 to 17 from a family below the poverty level. State educational agencies determine poverty criteria based on Census Bureau data adjusted for inflation. Local educational agencies report the number of eligible children enrolled in public and private schools annually. The State educational agency determines poverty criteria based on Census Bureau data, and local educational agencies report the number of eligible children enrolled in schools annually. The State educational agency allocates funds to local educational agencies based on the number of eligible children identified, which are then distributed to public and private schools within the local agency's jurisdiction. The State educational agency allocates funds based on poverty criteria determined from Census Bureau data, which are then distributed to public and private schools to supplement non-Federal resources for the education of eligible children. SEC. 201 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include home school expenses as qualified education expenses for Coverdell Education Savings Accounts. SEC. 202 eliminates the contribution limitation for Coverdell Education Savings Accounts. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding Coverdell education savings accounts. A prohibition on excess contributions is added, ensuring contributions do not exceed qualified education expenses. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2013. Additionally, Title III introduces 529 programs for elementary and secondary education expenses. Title III introduces 529 programs for pre-kindergarten, elementary, and secondary education expenses. Title III introduces 529 programs for pre-kindergarten, elementary, and secondary education expenses. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified education expenses, encompassing higher education expenses and pre-kindergarten through secondary education expenses. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified pre-kindergarten, elementary, and secondary education expenses, such as tuition, fees, books, supplies, and room and board for students at public, private, or religious schools. Expenses for room and board, uniforms, transportation, and supplementary items and services required by a school, as well as expenses for computer technology or equipment and Internet access for the beneficiary and their family during school years. The term 'school' includes pre-kindergarten through grade 12 institutions and is considered an eligible educational institution for Section 529 purposes. The amendment changes "qualified higher education" to "qualified education" in the Code. Effective date for the amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014.
